> Test3:
> 2m-3
> Test4:
> 3m-4

That's better, and if we assume that the time to test mocks is negligible (a
fair assumption), the execution time will indeed be acceptable.

The problem is that you now find yourself writing a lot of code (all the
mocks) just to emulate production code. I have a few problems with that:

- Writing mocks takes time, especially for packages not designed for this
(try mocking JMS factories or obscure JDBC drivers). It also forces you to
maintain an entire parallel hierarchy and basically reimplement entire API's
(which are sometimes based on concrete implementations and not interfaces).
That's a lot of code clutter. But worse:

- You are not testing exactly what goes in production. Introduce a subtle
bug in your mock (return null instead of a real value) and your tests will
pass on your test machines and fail in production.

Writing mocks should be an option, but the testing framework should let me
use dependencies and test production code if I so choose, and unfortunately,
JUnit is of no help there.
